paragraph.paragraph: The EiffelEnvision debugger includes an expression evaluator that evaluates expressions entered in the vcurfQuickWatchDialogBox 0 QuickWatch dialog box, in the vcurfWatchWindow 0 Watch , or in the vcurfAutosWindow 0 Autos or vcurfLocalsWindow 0 Locals windows. The expression evaluator is also at work in the vcurfBreakpointsWindow 0 Breakpoints Window . If you type the name of a function where you want to set a breakpoint, for example, the expression evaluator handles it.

The debugger uses auto-expand rules to display the contents of a data type in meaningful form. If you need to, you can add custom auto-expand elements to display your own custom data types. For more information, see vchowDisplayingElementsOfCustomDataType 0 Displaying Elements of a Custom Data Type .

Debugger expressions can use any identifier visible within the current scope. If the debugger is halted in function magh, for example, you can use any identifier visible within magh, including constants, and variable names.

The debugger can correctly display any variable of a primitive, or intrinsic type. For variables of class type, the debugger correctly displays the value based on the derived-most type. If you have an object leo of type LION, derived from type CAT, you can evaluate leo.claw_length and get the correct value for an object of type LION.

For ../../../../technologies/dotnet/eiffel_dotnet_language/index.xmlEiffel for .NET, you can assign a new value to any left-hand expression that us an l-value and has non-array type. This includes primitive, class, and SYSTEM_OBJECT (System.Object) types.
Evaluation of functions is not supported in EiffelEnvision.

EiffelEnvision supports all of the common infix operators in ../../../../technologies/dotnet/eiffel_dotnet_language/index.xmlEiffel for .NET. The following operators are valid in the expression:
350 4
centerSymbol Definition
center+ Plus
center- Minus
center* Multiply
center/ Divide
center// Integer Division
center\\ Remainder
center^ Power
centerlt; Lesser
centergt; Greater
centerlt;= Lesser or equal
centergt;= Greater or equal
center= Equal
center/= Not equal
centerAND And
centerAND THEN And then
centerOR Or
centerOR ELSE Or else
center@ Item at index, applies only to arrays.

EiffelEnvision supports two types of arrays. Eiffel ARRAYs and .NET NATIVE_ARRAY (System.Array). Both arrays may be indexed using the @ infix operator.
l_arr @ 1
The above expression will yield the value at index 1.

For multi-dimensional arrays, dimension indexes may be retrieved by grouping an @ with ():
( l_arr @ 3) @ 2

In EiffelEnvision you may write a string in the Watch window such as:
"Hello"
and it will correctly display. Strings entered in this way are SYSTEM_STRINGs (System.String) and not Eiffel STRINGs.

EiffelEnvision also supports the concatenation of strings.
"Hello" + "World"
would correctly display
"HelloWorld"
in the watching window. Variables of type SYSTEM_STRING can also be concatenated in the same way:
l_sys_str + "World"

Simple cast expressions work in the debugger:
(A)x
Evaluation property on .NET objects is not supported in EiffelEnvision. Evaluating a property in the debugger can have side effects that produce unexpected and undesired results.
